"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress recognizes the significance of the Brown v. Board of Education decision and the integration of the "Little Rock Nine" as a catalyst for desegregation in public schools. Central High School, a historic landmark, was a catalyst for integrating public schools in the US. It was recognized for its significance in the civil rights movement. The Little Rock Central High School was designated as a unit of the National Park System in 1982 to recognize its role in the civil rights movement and the desegregation of public schools in the South. The purpose of this Act is to preserve, protect, and interpret the school for present and future generations. Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas played a significant role in the integration of public schools and the civil rights movement in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as part of the National Park System in Arkansas. The site includes the Central High School campus in Little Rock and will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the historic site in accordance with applicable laws. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies. Central High School. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies, organizations, and institutions to further the purposes of this Act. Visitor interpretation of the historic site will be coordinated with the Little Rock School District and the Central High School Museum, Inc. Within 2 years, a general management plan will be prepared by the Secretary. The Secretary will prepare a general management plan for the historic site within 2 years. They will consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure the site's administration does not interfere with Central High School's educational use. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the site's boundaries. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the historic site's boundaries using purchased, donated, or appropriated funds, with consent from the owner. Lands owned by the State of Arkansas or a political subdivision can only be acquired through donation or exchange. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation in public education. The Secretary will prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education to identify new landmarks and establish linkages between sites for education and research. The High School National Historic Site was established to maximize opportunities for public education and research on desegregation in public education. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations to prepare the theme study for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. The theme study will be part of the general management plan for the site. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
